Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Local Adaptation in a Dominant Arctic Tundra Sedge (Eriophorum Vaginatum) and its Effects on Ecosystem Response in a Changing Climate
Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Local adaptation in a dominant arctic tundra sedge (Eriophorum vaginatum) and its effects on ecosystem response in a changing climate

Eriophorum vaginatum is presently a dominant component of moist tussock tundra, but is susceptible to competition from more rapidly growing deciduous shrubs under warming conditions. The project has three objectives: 1) to investigate the genetic factors that lead to local adaptation in E. vaginatum; 2) to examine natural disturbance as a mechanism for genotypes from warmer climates to establish in tussock tundra of northern regions; and 3) to test the hypothesis that local adaptation and adaptational lag will have important consequences for plant phenology, photosynthesis, primary productivity, plant growth, and nutrient cycling. The findings of this project may serve as an indicator of the potential effects of adaptational lag on plant responses to climate change. Research results will be integrated into the manual for the International Tundra Experiment, which has been a developing resource for long term Arctic research. The project directly involves undergraduate research experience for students at Wilkes, a largely undergraduate university, and University of Texas at El Paso, a minority serving institution. Marine Biological Laboratory also will involve students in the research directly through their Semester in Environmental Sciences program, which will involve students in analyzing data taken directly from the Arctic project. K-12 students in Wilkes-Barre will be involved in Arctic research by studying plants shipped from Alaska. K-12 students in El Paso will be exposed to Arctic research through already established programs that engage graduate students with high school students through presentations of research results.

The proposed research will use approaches from molecular ecology and population biology to investigate the causes of local adaptation in Eriophorum vaginatum. It will use methods of ecosystem ecology to investigate the consequences of local adaptation for the response of E. vaginatum to a rapidly warming climate. Genetic markers will be used to determine patterns of genetic diversity and gene flow for populations of E. vaginatum in northern Alaska. Uncovering the underlying genetic structure and population genetic dynamics will provide important insight into the ability for E. vaginatum to adapt to a changing climate. A recent burn site will be seeded with E. vaginatum from different populations with measures of seedling establishment and health followed by identifying genotype success utilizing molecular markers. The processes will be measured in gardens that include both transplants and plants exposed to warming with open-top chambers to simulate the combined effects of northward migration of southern ecotypes and climate warming.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The North Slope of the Brooks Range in Alaska is a vast region about the size and shape of the Florida Peninsula that is home to caribou, grizzly bears, and about 10,000 people. Most of the North Slope is covered by a carpet of tundra, which consists of grasses, sedges, shrubs, mosses, and lichens, but no trees. Under this carpet is a layer of peat that could double the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere if it were to decompose in a warming climate. The dominant plant over vast regions of the landscape is the tussock cottongrass (Eriophorum vaginatum). South of the Brooks Range the landscape changes at ?tree line?, the region where trees and shrubs become prevalent and tundra habitat is no longer dominant. South of tree line tussock cottongrass is found in ecological islands among the taiga forest.

    This project examined the genetic history and current genetic response of hypothesized cottongrass ecotypes under the context of climate change. Populations are designated as ecotypes if they display differences in their morphology or physiology that appear to have a genetic basis. Ecotypes that are adapted to local conditions may become unable to maintain themselves as climate changes. This phenomenon, called adaptive lag, is potentially significant for Arctic ecosystems where the climate is warming rapidly, and ecotypes of cottongrass occupy large areas. Long term studies have described tussock cottongrass ecotypes based on ecological response of plants, the focus of this study was to examine the genetic component of ecotype variation.

Two well established methods were used to study the genetics of tussock cottongrass ecotypes. First, we travelled along a latitudinal gradient in northeast east Alaska from north of Fairbanks to the coastal plains of Prudhoe Bay to collect leaves from tussock cottongrass in natural populations. From these leaves we took DNA to develop data to profile how plants from different parts of the range were related to each other and whether hypothesized ecotypes were supported. A second established method for determining if there is genetic evidence for ecotypes was to set up reciprocal transplant experiments, where plants from multiple sites are moved into common gardens at all sites. Plants can then be examined under common environmental conditions to determine if plants from different sites respond to environmental conditions differently. We established a set of reciprocal transplant Gardens in 2014 that included plants from north and south of tree line. We examined gene expression in one of these gardens on an average temperature day and a high temperature day. Plants can express different levels of genes in relation to ecological adaptations. For example if a plant species is adapted to warmer temperature in the southern part of  its range it will potentially express genes related to stress or physiological response differently than a plant from the north part of the range not adapted to warm weather.

    Reciprocal transplant experiments established in the 1980s among six populations of tussock cottongrass, along the latitudinal gradient used in this study, indicated that there were two ecotypes, one on the North Slope and the other south of the Brooks Range. Our genetic analysis support north/south ecotypes that are divided by tree line. Additionally we identified a third genetic group not recognized by ecological studies alone. This southernmost population is more geographically isolated than the others and occurs in a different environment. Further studies will determine if this is related to ecological specificity.

We found that on an average temperature day ecotypes differed little in expression of genes related to physiology, photosynthesis and stress. However on the day with high temperature northernmost ecotypes showed a pronounced difference in expression of genes related to stress response compared to other ecotypes suggesting support for local adaptation. This study identifies ecotype differences not easily measurable using traditional ecological studies or population genetics. As northern ecotypes show different response to higher temperature and our genetic analyses show that there is not movement of genes from south to north this supports the likely effects of adaptive lag. Therefore, the probability of adaptation to the warming climate through natural selection is not great. Instead, the abundance of tussock cottongrass may decline. Because of the important role of this species in the Arctic tundra ecosystem, patterns of plant production as well as nutrient mobilization and use are also likely to change, which could affect the stability of the peat layer, leading to greater emissions of greenhouse gases, carbon dioxide and methane.

  Undergraduates and graduate students from the University of Texas-El Paso and Wilkes University participated in the project as field and laboratory assistants. Training in STEM for underrepresented students at UTEP was advanced through research assistance on this project. The project supported a PhD student that is now in candidacy and due to complete in 2020.
